homes_hear_details: Kansas's HOMES and HEAR programs are pending launch. The Kansas Corporation Commission and Kansas Energy Office are developing implementation plans using approximately $40 million in IRA funding allocated to the state.

income_thresholds.low_income_80_ami: For a family of four in the Kansas City metro area (Kansas side), 80% AMI is approximately $62,000. Low-income households will qualify for the highest rebate levels under HOMES when launched.
income_thresholds.moderate_income_150_ami: For a family of four in the Kansas City metro area (Kansas side), 150% AMI is approximately $116,250. Moderate-income households will qualify for partial rebates under HOMES when launched.

net_metering: Kansas requires investor-owned utilities to offer net metering for systems up to 200 kW. Excess generation is credited at the retail rate on a monthly basis. Annual excess is purchased at the utility's avoided cost rate. Net metering policies for cooperatives and municipals may vary.

state_tax_credits.name: Kansas Renewable Energy Property Tax Exemption
state_tax_credits.amount: 100% property tax exemption for the added value of renewable energy systems for 10 years
state_tax_credits.eligible_items: Solar PV, solar thermal, wind energy, geothermal, and other renewable energy systems installed on residential or commercial properties
state_tax_credits.details: Kansas does not have a direct state income tax credit for solar, but renewable energy system installations are exempt from property tax increases for 10 years. This means the added value of the solar system will not increase property tax assessments.

state_rebate_programs.name: Kansas Weatherization Assistance Program
state_rebate_programs.eligible_items: Insulation, air sealing, furnace repair and replacement, duct sealing, window and door repairs
state_rebate_programs.details: Available to households at or below 200% of the federal poverty level. Administered through local community action agencies across Kansas.
